channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Carney Puts Ex-Goldman Banker, Quebec Loyalist in Key Jobs
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled his new economic team, keeping longtime politician François-Philippe Champagne as finance minister and placing former Goldman Sachs banker Timothy Hodgson in charge of energy and mining.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, arrives for a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney is set to unveil a new cabinet with many new faces who didn’t serve in Justin Trudeau's inner circle, according to an official with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: Harvard Feud With Trump Escalates as US Punches Back at Garber
item.description: Harvard University President Alan Garber has twice publicly rebuked the Trump administration for threatening the school’s independence. Both times the US government has punched back.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan, Janet Lorin, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The Trump administration froze billions of dollars of funds for Harvard University.

item.title: Trump Says Saudis to Invest $1 Trillion, Touting Deals in the US
item.description: President Donald Trump said Saudi Arabia would commit to investing $1 trillion in the US, promoting a flurry of dealmaking at the start of his four-day Middle East visit.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Hadriana Lowenkron, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Prince Mohammed bin Salman during a signing ceremony at the Saudi Royal Court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on May 13.

item.title: Colombian Business Lobby Warns of Risks From a Deal With China
item.description: Colombia’s business lobby warned of risks to local industry from President Gustavo Petro’s plan to join the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro speaks during the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) in Beijing on May 13.

item.title: Saudi King-in-Waiting Marks Ascent With Gilded Welcome for Trump
item.description: When US President Donald Trump touched down in Riyadh he was greeted by a Saudi leader who was in every respect a king — except for his official title.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at King Khalid International Airport on May 13.

item.title: Trump to Meet Syrian Leader in Riyadh, US Official Says
item.description: US President Donald Trump will briefly meet Syria’s new leader, Ahmed al-Sharaa, in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, according to a White House official.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Ahmed al-Sharaa

item.title: Trump Says Saudis to Invest $1 Trillion, Touting Deals in the US
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said the kingdom will boost investments in the US to $1 trillion.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 13: U.S. President Donald J. Trump leaves Saudi Royal Court with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on May 13, 2025, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Trump begins a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Reeves Says Never Say Never on Forcing UK Pension Investment
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said she didn’t rule out mandating pension funds to allocate money to UK assets, as the government seeks to channel more investment into the domestic economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Lizzy Burden, Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves signs the Mansion House Accord in the City of London on May 13.

item.title: US Slaps Sanctions on Network Shipping Iranian Oil to China
item.description: The US took a fresh step seeking to curb Iran’s oil revenues with sanctions on an international network that it said facilitates the shipment of millions of barrels to China, an effort by the Trump administration to further pressure Tehran while negotiating over its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: The impounded Iranian crude oil tanker, Grace 1, is silhouetted as it sits anchored off the coast of Gibraltar on Saturday, July 20, 2019. Tensions have flared in the Strait of Hormuz in recent weeks as Iran resists U.S. sanctions that are crippling its oil exports and lashes out after the seizure on July 4 of one of its ships near Gibraltar. Photographer: Marcelo del Pozo/Bloomberg

item.title: MIT, Yale Face Endowment Tax Hike While Notre Dame Scores Break
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said a Republican plan to raise taxes on college endowments would threaten US interests.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: A student walks through Library Walk at Yale University campus in New Haven, Connecticut, US, on Sunday April 7, 2024. A Bloomberg News analysis of more than 1,500 nonprofit four-year colleges shows the return on investment at many elite private institutions outside the eight Ivies is no better than far-less selective public universities.

item.title: Europe Awaits Turkey Summit to Push US on Russian Sanctions
item.description: European leaders are ready to wait until after a possible meeting between Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and Russia’s Vladimir Putin in Turkey before pushing the US to announce fresh sanctions on Moscow, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Alberto Nardelli, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin, left, and Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Source: AFP/Getty Images, Bloomberg/Bloomberg/Bloomberg

item.title: Demand Soars at South Africa Bond Sale as Risk Mood Lifts
item.description: Investor demand at South Africa’s weekly government bond sale more than doubled as risk appetite improved globally after the US and China reached a deal to temporarily lower tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mpho Hlakudi

item.title: Trump Diplomatic Blitz Spins Big Gambles as Signs of Success
item.description: It was the kind of week that would make even a seasoned diplomat’s head spin: China trade talks, India-Pakistan truce, a ceasefire with the Houthis and Iran nuclear negotiations. Not to mention a Gaza hostage release, new trade framework with the UK and the tantalizing prospect of ending Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: Zelenskiy Stands by Plan to Meet Putin in Turkey for Talks
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy reinforced his intention to hold direct talks with Vladimir Putin in Turkey on Thursday, even as the Russian leader offered no clarity on whether he’d show up.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv, on May 13. Photographer: Evgeniy Maloletka/AP Photo

item.title: Putin Hails Ramped Up Military Recruiting for War in Ukraine
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin hailed the recruitment of volunteers to fight in his war in Ukraine, suggesting the pace of efforts to replenish the ranks has significantly increased since last year.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Russian T-90M tanks drive through Moscow during a rehearsal for the Victory Day parade on May 3.

item.title: Poland’s Domanski Sees EU Defense Fund Agreement This Month
item.description: Polish Finance Minister Andrzej Domanski said he expects the European Union to reach a deal this month on a €150 billion ($167 billion) fund to boost the bloc’s defense capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Jorge Valero, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Andrzej Domanski, Poland's finance minster, during a news conference following the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) meeting at the European Council headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. A top European Union policymaker said the region should take advantage of investor doubts in the dollar and US Treasuries.

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu Vows to ‘Finish the Job’ of Destroying Hamas
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he’s days away from ordering an all-out escalation of Israel’s war against Hamas, and even the release of more hostages would only pause the campaign to destroy the Iran-backed group.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu

item.title: US Firm Global AI Secures Saudi Investment Worth Billions
item.description: Global AI, a US tech firm, plans to collaborate with a Saudi Arabian artificial intelligence venture, Humain, in an agreement expected to be worth billions of dollars, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

item.title: Venezuela Bond Market Gets Lift From Freeing of Political Aides
item.description: The surprise exit of a group of political opposition members from Caracas has brought new life to the beleaguered market for Venezuela’s defaulted bonds.
item.dc:creator: Nicolle Yapur

media:content.media:description: Residence Hall of the Embassy of the Republic of Argentina in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Prioritizes Trump Campaign Vows, Increases SALT
item.description: President Donald Trump’s campaign tax pledges — no taxes on tips and overtime pay, plus new tax breaks for car buyers and seniors — are the centerpiece of a multitrillion dollar package that will serve as Republicans’ signature legislative effort.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Ari Natter, Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Says EU Is Plagued by ‘Collective Action Problem’
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the European Union suffers from a “collective action problem” that’s hampering trade negotiations, downplaying the possibility of a quick agreement with the US’s largest trading relationship.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: India Proposes First Counter Move Against Trump’s Tariff Regime
item.description: India has proposed levies on some US goods in response to Washington’s duties on steel and aluminum, marking its first retaliation against President Donald Trump’s tariff regime, even as the two countries move closer to finalizing a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A crane is used to load stainless steel coils onto a train container at Jindal Stainless Ltd. plant in Jajpur, Odisha, India, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. India is scheduled to release industrial production figures on April 28. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: Egypt Cuts Canal Fees to Bring Ships After Trump-Houthi Deal
item.description: Egypt cut fees for some vessels crossing the Suez Canal, seeking to revive the critical trade route after the US agreed to a ceasefire with Yemeni militants attacking Red Sea shipping.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Tarek El-Tablawy

media:content.media:description: Ships sail along Egypt's Suez Canal near Ismailia on April 16.

item.title: SALT, Tips and Auto Loans: A Guide to the House GOP Tax Bill
item.description: House Republicans’ release of the tax provisions in their massive fiscal bill provides a crucial initial reading of what party leaders think could pass, culminating weeks of intense negotiations among fractious GOP lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: Customers at a Ford dealership in Richmond, California, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. US retail sales rose substantially in March on a jump in car purchases and other goods such as electronics, suggesting consumers were scrambling to get ahead of tariffs.

item.title: Lula and Xi Agree to Boost Chinese Presence in Brazil Despite Trump's Threats
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva insists he doesn’t want to pick between the US and China as his two largest trading partners wage a trade war. But it’s increasingly clear which side he has already chosen.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Leonardo Lara, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in 2024.

item.title: NATO’s Former Head Says Allies Must Counter Russia’s Arctic Rise
item.description: NATO must take a stronger role in the Arctic to deter increasing Russian activity, according to the alliance’s former secretary general.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Anders Fogh Rasmussen at the Copenhagen Democracy Summit on May 13.

item.title: Romania Is Headed for Tight Presidential Runoff, Poll Shows
item.description: Romania’s presidential runoff is shaping up to be a tight contest between a far-right party leader who stands to upend the Black Sea nation’s pro-European path and a contender promising a more centrist brand of leadership.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan at an electoral rally in Bucharest, Romania, on May 11.

item.title: Carney Plans Economy-Focused Cabinet With Fewer Trudeau Ministers
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is set to unveil a new cabinet with many new faces who didn’t serve in Justin Trudeau’s inner circle, according to an official with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney waves to supporters at his election victory party in Ottawa.

item.title: Goldman, JPMorgan Lift China Growth Outlook on US Tariff Truce
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other major banks boosted their growth forecasts for China’s economy, citing a temporary deal with the US to de-escalate their trade conflict.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: A worker loads bundles of goods onto a truck at an industrial park in Yiwu, Zhejiang Province, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Russian Oil Exports’ Value Crimped Again by Latest Price Slide
item.description: Earnings from crude shipments remain near two-year low despite uptick in flows
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.42 million barrels a day of crude in the four weeks to May 11.
